Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Strategic Planning of Internet Services in the Presence of User-Initiated Innovations: Implications for Network Neutrality

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Internet provides information services that are essential to society and generate great economic benefits. An important contributing factor for the explosive growth of the Internet has been the absence of usage fees, which has been made possible in large part by Best Effort Service, the historical service on the Internet. The absence of usage fees has made the Internet a breeding ground for new user-created applications. However, as the network has matured, it has become clear that Best Effort Service alone cannot meet users` expectations and also the Quality of Service requirements of newer, more sophisticated applications. These new requirements makes it necessary to consider usage fee-based Managed Services with guaranteed service performance. Whether allowing network providers to offer these services will negatively affect Best Effort Service and the character of the Internet are issues at the heart of the current Network Neutrality debate. This research project employs the methodology of Operations Research to address this important policy question. In the core are models and analysis of network providers' profit-maximizing planning in which the influence of user-initiated innovations plays a central role, which is new in analytic treatments. While short-term profit incentives may induce a provider to degrade Best Effort Service to push consumers to pay the usage fee and use the Managed Services, doing so suppresses the creation of user-initiated applications, which generate future demands, and thus new profit opportunities. By integrating the latter effect into the planning model, the study can inform network providers about the importance of Best Effort Service for their long-term prosperity. The investigators will also analyze how regulators can create a policy environment to leverage this effect to align private providers' profit incentive with public interest. If these goals are achieved, the research project will help society to avoid the difficult choice on Managed Services, and allow the Internet to benefit from an expanded scope of services while sustaining Best Effort Service at a high quality level.

This project will model and analyze business strategies of network service providers and investigate resulting implications for public policies that are pertinent to Network Neutrality. The first step will be to develop a multi-period planning model for providers to maximize profit by controlling infrastructure investment, bandwidth allocation, and service pricing. In a departure from previous approaches, the model features a feedback loop in which the provider's profit-maximizing decisions interact with user-initiated innovations. The strength of such interactions depends on many factors, such as price elasticity of demand, users' intolerance to delay, and positive network externality. By solving this extended planning model and studying optimal solutions, the dependencies will be quantified and conclusions will be drawn regarding how the presence of user-initiated innovations affect network providers' incentive for preserving the quality of Best Effort Service in various scenarios. The model and analysis will then be applied to two case studies on Sponsored Data Service and Content Delivery Networks, respectively. The results will be used for empirical validation and refinements to the model. The discussion on public policies will focus on enhancing the incentive for offering Best Effort Service that is gained from user-initiated innovations. The treatment will be carried out in a multi-provider environment. In such an environment a provider can benefit from innovations that are the results of other providers' high-quality Best Effort Service, even though the quality of its own Best Effort Service is sub- standard. To counter the resulting free-rider problem, different policy alternatives derived from experiences with past network systems and approaches taken by other countries will be analyzed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The broadband Internet has become a ubiquitous communication ecosystem that serves as not only pipelines for information delivery, but also platforms to support multi-sided market transactions. The Internet infrastructure is owned and operated by many private enterprises that are motivated by profit maximization and involved in both competitive and collaborative relationships. The enormity of Internet’s impacts on the national economy and the general welfare of the society naturally raises the question as to what extent regulatory policies, especially Net Neutrality rules, need to be imposed to induce socially-desirable outcomes in terms of infrastructure development, content and service innovations, protection of consumer benefits, etc. The issue is being rigorously debated in economics, engineering, and many other research disciplines, as well as business and policy communities.

In this research, we study profit-maximizing behaviors in the broadband Internet. We model and analyze strategic planning and operational tactics, including capacity investment, quality-of-service (QoS) provisioning, and pricing policies, of Internet Service Providers (ISPs). Under the game theory and Nash bargaining solution frameworks, we also study ISPs’ interactions with other Internet enterprises, in particular information content providers (CPs).  By introducing new models and deriving novel results, the research contributes to the interdisciplinary literature on network economics. By examining the self-interests of Internet service and content providers and considering various tradeoffs involved in decision-making and interactions, our work yields informative insights to a broader community, including ISPs and regulators, on implications of Internet policies related to the Net Neutrality debate.

For instance, we have studied a common situation in which an ISP provides the Best Effort service, which has flexible QoS and no usage fee, to the mass market.  It also offers a premium Managed Service with guaranteed QoS and usage-based service charge.  Our analysis shows that the proliferation of user-generated applications can serve as a counterweight against myopic incentives to degrade QoS of the Best Effort service to gain more profit from the Managed Service. In other words, ISPs should sustain the Best Effort service because they can benefit from the positive externalities generated by the use of the service.

We have also studied emerging relationships between ISPs and CPs (e.g., Comcast-Netflix). Specifically, we investigate how business incentive, industry organization, and Net Neutrality regulation can affect the deployment and interconnection of content storage facilities (caches) and the deployment of the ``last mile’’ incremental bandwidth. Our results show that when the ISP and CP operate as a single integrated company, Net Neutrality regulation makes quantitative, but not fundamental differences in caching deployment and interconnection.  However, if the two companies carry out separate operations to maximize their own profits, the regulation can exert very significant influence on the deployment of caches.  

 A major outcome of our research is the realization that specific differences in the model of business interactions between players, even if they share common goals, can lead to unexpectedly large divergences in benefits, to the players, their consumers, and society. Take for example a Stackelberg game between the last-mile broadband ISP, the leader, and the Content Provider, the follower. In this setting both players want to deploy caches and extra bandwidth over the last mile to improve subscribers’ Quality of Experience, and thereby increase the number of subscribers. Consider a change in the model of interaction between the ISP and multiple Content Providers to a consortium of players with equal bargaining powers. Include fixed costs, which is realistic when infrastructure investments are necessary. Since this is a model in non-cooperative games, an essential new component is the bargaining that precedes the formation of the consortium, which yields decisions regarding revenue and cost sharing during operations. We have found in our research on consortiums that, first, profit sharing is egalitarian; second, there needs to be a form of admission control to the consortium so that subsidies from any subset of members to any other subset are not excessive; third, the end results in terms of aggregate profit to the players, consumer and social welfare, and investments in infrastructure, with and without Net Neutrality regulations, are all significantly superior to comparable metrics derived from the Stackelberg model. Since we have not found results of this nature in the literature, it has been eye-opening. We have been motivated to investigate the possibility of consortiums in other settings, such as infrastructure sharing in 5G.

The research has produced many publications in peer-reviewed proceedings of engineering and public policy conferences, including IEEE INFOCOM and TPRC: Research Conference on Communication, Information, and Internet Policy. Our findings have also been presented at other professional outlets such as IEEE Workshop on Smart Data Pricing and INFORMS Annual Conferences. The project provides opportunities for training graduate students in Internet policies and network economics: some students have worked on technical analysis of the aforementioned models to complete their master programs in Electrical Engineering.
